trial_identification.studytitle: Infant-Centered Feeding in a low income population
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Early Intervention for the Reduction of Childhood Obesity in Low-Income Populations: A home based Randomized Controlled Trial to assess the effect of infant-centered feeding on maternal responsiveness, feeding styles and feeding practices (Healthy Babies Intervention Trial)

interventions.interventions: Healthy Babies Infant-centered feeding from birth - 1 year old. Intervention implemented through 6 in-home lessons before infant is 6 months old In-home lesson content for infant-centered feeding involves - interpreting hunger and satiety cues and introduction to solid foods Duration of lessons - 60-80 minutes Sessions occur weekly or monthly form birth to 6 months of age (based on age of infant at enrollment) Mode of Administration - Lessons are taught be trained paraprofessional nutrition instructors
interventions.comparator: Healthy Families - Active control Standard treatment of 6 in-home nutrition lessons Duration of Lessons - 60-80 minutes Administered - weekly or monthly from birth to 6 months of age (based on age of infant at enrollment) Mode of Administration - taught by trained paraprofessional nutrition instructors

primaryOutcome.outcome: Maternal Responsiveness - total score on Parent Child Interaction Feeding Scale
Feeding Styles - mean score on Infant Feeding Styles questionnaire (Bentley et al)
Feeding Practices - frequencies on Infant Feeding checklist

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Infant weight/length - standardized measurements will be done according to Centers for Disease Control (CDC) guidelines. An infant's weight will be obtained with a scale measuring mass to the nearest ounce, a recumbent length will be used where the infant will be lying down on a flat surface and measurement taken from the top of the infant's head to heel and measured in inches. A z score will be computed for the infant's weight-for-length plotted over time. Categories will be created according to CDC age/sex-specific growth charts, normal (5th through 84th percentile) versus not normal (either below 5th or above 85th or higher of weight-for-length)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Low-income population with infants less than 4 months and not started on solid foods
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Male parents Premature infants with low birthweight or feeding disorders

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Michigan State University 515-G west Fee Hall East Lansing MI 48224

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Healthy Babies The goal of this research study is implementation of a relationship skill-building and educational intervention, Healthy Babies (HB) through Infant-Centered Feeding that promotes the development of healthy infant feeding and grwoth through mothers' engagement in infant-centered feeding. objectives are to evaluate effectiveness of the Healthy Babies intervention in the development of infant-centered feeding (defined as maternal responsiveness, feeding style, and feeding practices) as infants transition to solid foods, and infant growth. Healthy Babies, implemented be trained nutrition paraprofessional instrutors, consist of 6 lessona and 3 telephone contact. we expect intervention participants will demonstrate greater increases over time in responsiveness and infant-centered feeding style and feeding practices compared to control participants. The long-term goal of this study is to improve low-income, at risk infants' nutrition and health by addressing childhood obesity through effective intervention promoting the development of healthy eating habits at an early age.
